title: For first time, Earth's single-day CO2 tops 400 ppm
content:
The global concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere
hit 400 parts per million for the first time in recorded history on Thursday,
according to data from the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii.
Since 1958, the Mauna Loa Observatory has been
gathering data on how much carbon dioxide is in the atmosphere.  Carbon dioxide has increased by about 24
percent since the beginning of this record. Thursday's level was an unprecedented 400.03 ppm. (Source: NOAA)
Carbon dioxide is an important heat-trapping (greenhouse)
gas, which is released through human activities such as deforestation and
burning fossil fuels, as well as natural processes such as respiration and
volcanic eruptions.  It is the primary driver
of recent global climate change.
